cluster_relations.rel_desc: Birds consume fruits as part of their feeding behavior.
Birds feed on pest organisms, acting as natural pest control agents.
remarks: Maps 'insects' in text to the pest concept provided.

qualifiers.OtherQualifier: Pollination mutualism: nectar reward for pollen transfer
Pollination mutualism: nectar reward for pollen transfer

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism feeds on the object resource as part of its diet or trophic behavior.
args.justification: The relation describes birds consuming fruits as part of feeding behavior; normalizing the predicate to the more general ecological term 'feeds_on' is appropriate and reusable across trophic interactions that are not strictly predation.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject organism acts as a predator on the object organism, reducing its population through predation.
args.justification: The description and hint explicitly frame birds as natural pest control agents by preying on pests; the predator–prey interaction is best captured by the canonical predicate 'preys_on'.

args.canonical_rel_desc: Subject pollinator transfers pollen between individuals of the object plant taxon, contributing to its reproduction.
args.justification: Both relations describe bird species (hummingbirds, sunbirds) performing pollination services for plant species; they share identical semantics of a pollination interaction, so they should be normalized under the same canonical predicate 'pollinates'.

Both relations describe feeding interactions where birds obtain energy/biomass from other organisms or their parts (fruits, pests); these are classic trophic interactions and belong in the same relation class.

Both relations describe mutualistic pollination interactions between bird pollinators and pollination-dependent plant species, which is distinct from trophic-only interactions and merits its own relation class.

All four relations describe ecological interactions between organisms (feeding, predation, pollination); they are best grouped under a broad interaction semantics rather than composition, identity, or causality.
